Award.AwardTitle: Conference: The 20th Penn State Plant Biology Symposium: Plant Stress-Omics in a Changing Climate to be held at Penn State University, College Park, PA from May 13-16, 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 20th Penn State plant Biology Symposium will focus on the important topic of "Plant Stress-Omics in a Changing Climate". Plenary sessions are focused on water and salinity, atmosphere (temperature, CO2, ozone), biotic/abiotic interactions and the use of novel tools. The conference is held at Penn State University, University Park takes place May 13-16, 2015. There will be two formal poster and two short talk sessions to feature research from talented junior scientists. The conference includes an impressive cadre of US and international speakers. The organizing committee and speaker list seems balanced in terms of broadening participation.

The workshop addresses an important topic in Plant Biology, namely how plants deal with increasing environmental stresses. Particularly noteworthy is a planned workshop preceding the meeting to provide training in novel mass spectrometric methods. These methods are necessary to determine metabolomics changes in response to various environmental stresses. The meeting is an ideal forum for students and postdocs to identify future mentors, and for established scientists to forge meaningful collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human population growth and our changing environment are presenting major challenges to sustainable food production and to maintenance of healthy natural ecosystems. Plant biologists are developing and applying new integrative Big Data approaches to address these challenges. The symposium, “Plant Stress-Omics in a Changing Climate”, held at The Pennsylvania State University on May 13-16, 2015, was designed to showcase research from scientists who are working at a diversity of -omics levels to elucidate impacts of environmental stresses on plants and to develop solutions for agricultural sustainability and ecosystem preservation. Such research can help to ameliorate negative effects of our changing climate on agricultural and natural ecosystems, so this research is vital to global agriculture and ecosystem health. Presentations at this symposium included 18 plenary lectures, 9 short talks, 2 workshops on scientific techniques, and 62 scientific posters. There were 125 conference participants from a total of eight different countries, reflecting the international nature of modern scientific research. Funds from the National Science Foundation were used in support of participation in this symposium of young scientists and those in under-represented groups. The symposium schedule facilitated interactions among a diverse array of accomplished researchers working in complementary fields, and between those researchers and beginning faculty members, postdoctorates, and students, providing many opportunities for networking and development of new research collaborations.
